1088.a.Problem Statement:
Consider a damped, driven harmonic oscillator (in one dimension) with equation of motion

$$
m \ddot{x}=-m \omega_{0}^{2} x-\gamma \dot{x}+A \cos (\omega t) .
$$

What is the time-averaged rate of energy dissipation?
1088.a.Solution:
The equation of motion is the real part of

$$
m \ddot{z}+m \omega_{0}^{2} z+\gamma \dot{z}=A e^{i \omega t} .
$$

For the steady-state solution we $\operatorname{try} z=z_{0} e^{i \omega t}$. Substitution gives

$$
z_{0}=\frac{A}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+i \gamma \omega}=B e^{-i \phi},
$$

with

$$
B=\frac{A}{\sqrt{m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)^{2}+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}}}, \quad \phi=\arctan \frac{\gamma \omega}{m\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)} .
$$

The rate of work done by the force $F=\operatorname{Re}\left(A e^{i \omega t}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P &=\operatorname{Re} F \cdot \operatorname{Re} \dot{z}=\frac{1}{4}\left(F+F^{*}\right)\left(\dot{z}+\dot{z}^{*}\right) \\
&=\frac{1}{4}\left(F \dot{z}+F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}+F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right)=\frac{1}{4}\left(F^{*} \dot{z}+F \dot{z}^{*}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

when averaged over one period as $F \dot{z}$ and $F^{*} \dot{z}^{*}$ each carries a time factor $e^{\pm 2 i \omega t}$ which vanishes on integration over one period. Thus the average work done is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle P\rangle &=\frac{i \omega A B}{4}\left(e^{-i \varphi}-e^{i \varphi}\right)=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \sin \varphi \\
&=\frac{\omega A B}{2} \frac{B}{A} \gamma \omega=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} B^{2}}{2}=\frac{\gamma \omega^{2} A^{2}}{2\left[m^{2}\left(\omega_{0}^{2}-\omega^{2}\right)+\gamma^{2} \omega^{2}\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

In steady state, this is equal to the rate of energy dissipation of the oscillator, which is given by the work done against the dissipative term, i.e.

$$
\left\langle P^{\prime}\right\rangle=\gamma(R e \dot{z})^{2}=\gamma \frac{\dot{z} \dot{z}^{*}}{2}=\gamma \frac{\omega^{2} B^{2}}{2} .
$$

As noted, the two approaches give the same result.

1016.b.Problem Statement:
A mass $m$ moves in a circle on a smooth horizontal plane with velocity $v_{0}$ at a radius $R_{0}$. The mass is attached to a string which passes through a smooth hole in the plane as shown in the figure.
("Smooth" means frictionless.)

What is the angular momentum of $m$?
1016.b.Solution: The tension in the string provides the centripetal force needed for the circular motion, hence $F=m v_{0}^{2} / R_{0}$.The angular momentum of the mass $m$ is $J=m v_{0} R_{0}$.

1115.Problem Statement: A projectile of mass $m$ is shot (at velocity $V$) at a target of mass $M$, with a hole containing a spring of constant $k$. The target is initially at rest and can slide without friction on a horizontal surface (see the figure). Find the distance $\Delta x$ that the spring compresses at maximum.
1115.Solution:
At the instant the spring compresses at maximum, the projectile $m$ and the target $M$ move with the same velocity $V_{e}$. Conservation of energy

$$
\frac{m V^{2}}{2}=\frac{m V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{M V_{e}^{2}}{2}+\frac{k(\Delta x)^{2}}{2},
$$

and conservation of momentum

$$
m V=(m+M) V_{e}
$$

give

$$
\Delta x=\sqrt{\frac{m M}{k(m+M)}} V .
$$

1199.Problem Statement: A thin uniform stick of mass $m$ with its bottom end resting on a frictionless table is released from rest at an angle $\theta_{0}$ to the vertical (see the figure). Find the force exerted by the table upon the stick at an infinitesimally small time after its release.
1199.Solution:
As there is no friction, the forces acting on the stick are the normal support $N$ and the gravity $m g$ as shown in Fig. 1.168. Within an infinitesimal time of the release of the stick, the equations of motion are

$$
\begin{aligned}
N-m g &=m \ddot{y}, \\
\frac{1}{2} N L \sin \theta_{0} &=\frac{1}{12} m L^{2} \ddot{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $y$ is the vertical coordinate of the center of mass and $\frac{1}{12} m L^{2}$ is the moment of inertia about a horizontal axis through the center of mass of the stick. As

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y=\frac{1}{2} L \cos \theta, \\
&\ddot{y}=-\frac{1}{2} L\left(\dot{\theta}^{2} \cos \theta+\ddot{\theta} \sin \theta\right)=-\frac{1}{2} L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

as initially

$$
\dot{\theta}=0, \quad \theta=\theta_{0} .
$$

Hence 

$$
\begin{aligned}
N &=m g+m \ddot{y} \\
&=m g-\frac{1}{2} m L \ddot{\theta} \sin \theta_{0} \\
&=m g-3 N \sin ^{2} \theta_{0},
\end{aligned}
$$

or

$$
N=\frac{m g}{1+3 \sin ^{2} \theta_{0}} .
$$

3041.b.Problem Statement:
A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

What is the magnitude of the particle's momentum in the center of mass frame?
3041.b.Solution:
Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$In the center of mass frame, the total momentum $P^{\prime}=0$ and $p$ the momentum of the particle is equal and opposite to that of the photon $p^{\prime}$. Momentum transformation

$$
P^{\prime}=0=\gamma\left(P-\frac{\beta E}{c}\right)
$$

gives

$$
\beta=\frac{P c}{E}=\frac{p c}{p c+m c^{2}}, \quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}
$$

for the center of mass frame. The particle momentum in the center of mass frame is then, using the transformation equation again,

$$
p^{\prime}=\gamma(0-\beta m c)=-\gamma \beta m c=\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}} .
$$
3041.b.Final Answer: $$\frac{-p m c}{\sqrt{2 p m c+m^{2} c^{2}}}$$

1080.Problem Statement: A mass $m$ moves in a plane in uniform circular motion with angular frequency $\omega$. The centripetal force is provided by a spring whose force constant is $K$ (ignore gravity). A very small radial impulse is given to the mass. Find the frequency of the resulting radial oscillation.
1080.Solution:
In polar coordinates the equations of motion for the mass are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&m\left(\ddot{r}-r \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)=-K\left(r-r_{0}\right), \\
&m(r \ddot{\theta}+2 \dot{r} \dot{\theta})=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

The second equation gives

$$
r^{2} \theta=\text { const. }
$$

Let $R$ be the radius of the uniform circular motion of the mass. We have

$$
m R \omega^{2}=K\left(R-r_{0}\right), \quad r^{2} \dot{\theta}=R^{2} \omega .
$$

Let $r^{\prime}=r-R$ for departure from uniform circular motion. The radial equation can be written as

$$
\ddot{r}-\frac{r^{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{r^{3}}=\ddot{r}^{\prime}-\frac{R^{4} \omega^{2}}{\left(R+r^{\prime}\right)^{3}}=-\frac{K}{m}\left(r^{\prime}+R-r_{0}\right) .
$$

If the radial impulse is very small, $r^{\prime} \ll R$ and the above becomes

$$
\ddot{r^{\prime}}-R \omega^{2}\left(1-\frac{3 r^{\prime}}{R}\right)=\frac{-K r^{\prime}}{m}-\frac{K\left(R-r_{0}\right)}{m},
$$

or

$$
\ddot{r}^{\prime}+\left(3 \omega^{2}+\frac{K}{m}\right) r^{\prime}=0 .
$$

It follows that the frequency of radial oscillation is $\omega^{\prime}=\sqrt{3 \omega^{2}+\frac{K}{m}}$.

1022.Problem Statement:
Calculate the ratio of the mean densities of the earth and the sun from the following approximate data:

$\theta=$ angular diameter of the sun seen from the earth $=\frac{1}{2}^{\circ}$.

$l=$ length of $1^{\circ}$ of latitude on the earth's surface $=100 \mathrm{~km}$.

$t=$ one year $=3 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}$.

$g=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}$.
1022.Solution:
Let $r$ be the distance between the sun and the earth, $M_{e}$ and $M_{s}$ be the masses and $R_{e}$ and $R_{s}$ be the radii of the earth and the sun respectively, and $G$ be the gravitational constant. We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\frac{G M_{e} M_{s}}{r^{2}}=M_{e} r \omega^{2}, \\
&\frac{2 R_{s}}{r}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{2 \pi}{360}=\frac{\pi}{360} \mathrm{rad},
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e.

$$
r=\frac{720 R_{s}}{\pi} .
$$

The above gives

$$
\frac{G M_{s}}{\left(720 R_{s} / \pi\right)^{3}}=\omega^{2}
$$

or

$$
\frac{G M_{s}}{R_{s}^{3}}=\left(\frac{720}{\pi}\right)^{3}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3 \times 10^{7}}\right)^{2} .
$$

For a mass $m$ on the earth's surface,

$$
\frac{G m M_{e}}{R_{e}^{2}}=m g,
$$

giving

$$
\frac{G M_{e}}{R_{e}^{3}}=\frac{g}{R_{e}}=\frac{g}{\left(\frac{360 \times 100}{2 \pi}\right)}=\frac{g \pi}{18 \times 10^{3}}
$$

Hence

$$
\frac{\rho_{e}}{\rho_{s}}=\frac{g \pi}{18 \times 10^{3}}\left(\frac{720}{\pi}\right)^{-3}\left(\frac{2 \pi}{3 \times 10^{7}}\right)^{-2}=3.31
$$

1202.Problem Statement: A uniform solid ball of radius $a$ rolling with velocity $v$ on a level surface collides inelastically with a step of height $h<a$, as shown in the figure. Find, in terms of $h$ and $a$, the minimum velocity for which the ball will "trip" up over the step. Assume that no slipping occurs at the impact point, and remember that the moment of inertia of a solid sphere with respect to an axis through its center is $\frac{2}{5} M a^{2}$.
1202.Solution:
Let $\omega$ and $\omega^{\prime}, J$ and $J^{\prime}$ be the angular velocity of the ball with respect to its center of mass and its angular momentum about the point of impact $A$ before and after collision with the step, respectively. We have

$$
J=m v(a-h)+\frac{2}{5} m a^{2} \omega=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h
$$

as $v=a \omega$ for rolling without slipping, and

$$
J^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}\right) \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}
$$

as the center of mass of the ball is momentarily at rest after the collision. Conservation of angular momentum requires

$$
\frac{7}{5} m a^{2} \omega^{\prime}=\frac{7}{5} m v a-m v h,
$$

yielding

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right) \frac{v}{a} .
$$

In order that the ball can just trip up over the step, its kinetic energy must be sufficient to provide for the increase in potential energy:

$$
\frac{1}{2} I^{\prime} \omega^{\prime 2}=m g h,
$$

where $I^{\prime}=\frac{2}{5} m a^{2}+m a^{2}=\frac{7}{5} m a^{2}$ is the moment of inertia of the ball about a horizontal axis through $A$. Hence the minimum velocity required is given by

$$
\frac{7}{10} m a^{2}\left(1-\frac{5 h}{7 a}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{v}{a}\right)^{2}=m g h,
$$

yielding

$$
v=\frac{a \sqrt{70 g h}}{7 a-5 h} .
$$

3025.c.Problem Statement:
In high energy proton-proton collisions, one or both protons may "diffractively dissociate" into a system of a proton and several charged pions. The reactions are

(1) $p+p \rightarrow p+(p+n \pi)$,

(2) $p+p \rightarrow(p+n \pi)+(p+m \pi)$.

Here $n$ and $m$ count the number of produced pions.

In the laboratory frame, an incident proton of total energy $E$ (the projectile) strikes a proton at rest (the target). Find the incident proton energy $E_{0}$ that is the minimum energy for reaction (2) to take place when both protons dissociate into a proton and 4 pions.

$$
m_{\pi}=0.140 \mathrm{GeV}, \quad m_{p}=0.938 \mathrm{GeV} .
$$
3025.c.Solution:
The energy for the reaction

$$
p+p \rightarrow p+(p+4 \pi)
$$

is minimum when all the final particles are at rest in an inertial frame, particularly the center of mass frame $\Sigma^{\prime}$. Then in the laboratory frame $\Sigma$,

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=\left(E_{0}+m_{p}\right)^{2}-\left(E_{0}^{2}-m_{p}^{2}\right)=2 m_{p} E_{0}+2 m_{p}^{2},
$$

and in $\Sigma^{\prime}$,

$$
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2}=\left(2 m_{p}+4 m_{\pi}\right)^{2}
$$

so that

$$
2 m_{p} E_{0}=2 m_{p}^{2}+16 m_{p} m_{\pi}+16 m_{\pi}^{2}
$$

giving

$$
E_{0}=\frac{m_{p}^{2}+8 m_{p} m_{\pi}+8 m_{\pi}^{2}}{m_{p}}=2.225 \mathrm{GeV}
$$

as the minimum energy the incident proton must have to cause the reaction.Since both the initial particles are protons and the final state particles are the same as before, the minimum energy remains the same, $2.225 \mathrm{GeV}$.For the reaction

$$
p+p \rightarrow(p+4 \pi)+(p+4 \pi)
$$

we have

$$
\left(E_{0}+m_{p}\right)^{2}-\left(E_{0}^{2}-m_{p}^{2}\right)=\left(2 m_{p}+8 m_{\pi}\right)^{2},
$$

giving the minimum incident energy as

$$
E_{0}=\frac{m_{p}^{2}+16 m_{p} m_{\pi}+32 m_{\pi}^{2}}{m_{p}}=3.847 \mathrm{GeV} .
$$

1135.Problem Statement: Use the rocket equation to find the rocket residual mass $m$ (in terms of the initial mass) at which the momentum of the rocket is a maximum, for a rocket of mass $m$ starting at rest in free space. The exhaust velocity is a constant $v_{0}$.
1135.Solution:
The equation of motion for a rocket, velocity $v$, in free space is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{d t},
$$

i.e.

Integrating, we obtain

$$
d v=\frac{-v_{0} d m}{m} .
$$

$$
v=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right),
$$

where $m_{0}$ is the rocket mass at firing. The momentum of the rocket is

$$
P=m v=-m v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right) .
$$

For it to be a maximum, we require

$$
\frac{d P}{d m}=-v_{0} \ln \left(\frac{m}{m_{0}}\right)-v_{0}=0 .
$$

Hence the rocket has maximum momentum when its residual mass is

$$
m=\frac{m_{0}}{e} .
$$

1206.Problem Statement: A particle of mass $m$ and speed $v$ collides elastically with the end of a uniform thin rod of mass $M$ as shown in the figure. After the collision, $m$ is stationary. Calculate $M$.
1206.Solution:
Let $v_{c}$ be the velocity of the center of mass of the rod and $\omega$ the angular velocity of the rod about the center of mass. Conservation of momentum and that of energy of this system give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m v &=M v_{c}, \\
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2} &=\frac{1}{2} M v_{c}^{2}+\frac{1}{2} I \omega^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $I=\frac{1}{12} M l^{2}, l$ being the length of the rod. Conservation of the angular momentum of the system about a fixed point located at the center of the rod before collision gives

$$
\frac{1}{2} l m v=I \omega .
$$

The above equations give

$$
M=4 m .
$$

1143.Problem Statement: A spherical dust particle falls through a water mist cloud of uniform density such that the rate of accretion onto the droplet is proportional to the volume of the mist cloud swept out by the droplet per unit time. If the droplet starts from rest in the cloud, find the value of the acceleration of the drop for large times.
1143.Solution:
Suppose the spherical dust particle initially has mass $M_{0}$ and radius $R_{0}$. Take the initial position of the dust particle as the origin and the $x$-axis along the downward vertical. Let $M(t)$ and $R(t)$ be the mass and radius of the droplet at time $t$ respectively. Then

$$
M(t)=M_{0}+\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(R^{3}-R_{0}^{3}\right) \rho,
$$

where $\rho$ is the density of the water mist, giving

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\rho 4 \pi R^{2} \frac{d R}{d t} .
$$

The droplet has a cross section $\pi R^{2}$ and sweeps out a cylinder of volume $\pi R^{2} \dot{x}$ in unit time, where $\dot{x}$ is its velocity. As the rate of accretion is proportional to this volume, we have

$$
\frac{d M}{d t}=\alpha \pi R^{2} \dot{x},
$$

$\alpha$ being a positive constant. Hence

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \dot{R} .
$$

The momentum theorem gives

$$
M(t+d t) \dot{x}(t+d t)-M(t) \dot{x}(t)=M g d t .
$$

Using Taylor's theorem to expand $M(t+d t)$ and $\dot{x}(t+d t)$ and retaining only the lowest-order terms, we obtain

$$
\dot{x} \frac{d M}{d t}+M \ddot{x}=M g .
$$

For large $t, M(t) \approx \frac{4}{3} \pi R^{3} \rho, d M / d t \approx 3 M \dot{R} / R$, and the above becomes

$$
\ddot{R}+\frac{3 \dot{R}^{2}}{R}=\frac{\alpha g}{4 \rho} .
$$

For a particular solution valid for large $t$, setting

$$
R(t)=a t^{2},
$$

where $a$ is a constant, in the above we obtain

$$
a=\frac{\alpha g}{56 \rho} .
$$

Thus for large $t$,

$$
\dot{x}=\frac{4 \rho}{\alpha} \cdot 2 a t=\frac{g t}{7} .
$$

Hence the acceleration for large times is $g / 7$.

1272.a.Problem Statement:
A sphere of radius $R$ moves with uniform velocity $\mathbf{u}$ in an incompressible ($\nabla \cdot \mathbf{v}(x)=0, \mathbf{v}(x)$ being the velocity of the fluid), non-viscous, ideal fluid.

Determine the velocity $\mathbf{v}$ of the fluid passing any point on the surface of the sphere.
1272.a.Solution:
At a point $(R, \theta)$ on the sphere the velocity of the fluid is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{v} &=-\nabla \phi=\left[-\frac{\partial \phi}{\partial r} \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{\partial \phi}{r \partial \theta} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}\right]_{r=R} \\
&=-\frac{1}{2} u R^{3}\left[\frac{2}{r^{3}} \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}+\frac{\sin \theta}{r^{3}} \mathbf{e}_{\theta}\right]_{r=R} \\
&=-u \cos \theta \mathbf{e}_{r}-\frac{1}{2} u \sin \theta \mathbf{e}_{\theta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

1113.Problem Statement:
Two steel spheres, the lower of radius $2 a$ and the upper of radius $a$, are dropped from a height $h$ (measured from the center of the large sphere) above a steel plate as shown in the figure. Assuming the centers of the spheres always lie on a vertical line and all collisions are elastic, what is the maximum height the upper sphere will reach?

Hint: Assume the larger sphere collides with the plate and recoils before it collides with the small sphere.
1113.Solution:
Let the mass of the smaller sphere be $m_{1}$ and that of the larger one $m_{2}$. Then $m_{2}=8 m_{1}$. The landing velocity of the larger sphere is $v_{2}=$ $\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}$ and its velocity immediately after bouncing back from the steel plate is still $v$ in magnitude. At this point, the descending velocity of the smaller sphere is $v_{1}=\sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}=v_{2}$. Let the velocities of the larger and smaller spheres after elastic collision be $v_{2}^{\prime}$ and $v_{1}^{\prime}$ respectively and take the upward direction as positive. Conservation of momentum and of mechanical energy give

$$
\begin{aligned}
m_{2} v_{2}-m_{1} v_{1} &=m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime}+m_{1} v_{2}^{\prime} \\
\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{2}}{2}+\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{2}}{2} &=\frac{m_{2} v_{2}^{\prime 2}}{2}+\frac{m_{1} v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

whose solution is

$$
\begin{aligned}
&v_{2}^{\prime}=\frac{5 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{5}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)}, \\
&v_{1}^{\prime}=\frac{23 v_{2}}{9}=\frac{23}{9} \sqrt{2 g(h-2 a)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Conservation of the mechanical energy of the smaller sphere thus gives the maximum height (measured from the steel plate) of the smaller sphere as

$$
H=3 a+\frac{v_{1}^{\prime 2}}{2 g}=3 a+\frac{529}{81}(h-2 a) .
$$

3050.a.Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons is scattered by a fixed scattering target as shown in the figure. The electrons are elastically scattered. Each electron has an energy $E=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}$ and the beam has a flux of $Q$ electrons per second.

What is the velocity of the incident electrons?
3050.a.Solution: As $E=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=\frac{5}{3}$ and $\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\frac{4}{5}$. Hence the electron velocity is $0.8 c$.

1001.a.Problem Statement:
A man of weight $w$ is in an elevator of weight $w$. The elevator accelerates vertically up at a rate $a$ and at a certain instant has a speed $V$.

What is the apparent weight of the man?
1001.a.Solution:
The apparent weight of the man is

$$
F=w+\frac{w}{g} a=w\left(1+\frac{a}{g}\right),
$$

$g$ being the acceleration of gravity.

1003.Problem Statement: In an amusement park there is a rotating horizontal disk. A child can sit on it at any radius (see the figure). As the disk begins to "speed up", the child may slide off if the frictional force is insufficient. The mass of the child is $50 \mathrm{~kg}$ and the coefficient of friction is $0.4$. The angular velocity is $2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$. What is the maximum radius $R$ where he can sit and still remain on the disk?
1003.Solution:
Under the critical circumstance that the child just starts to slide,

$$
m R \omega^{2}=\mu m g .
$$

Hence

$$
R=\frac{\mu g}{\omega^{2}}=\frac{0.4 \times 9.8}{2^{2}}=0.98 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

As the centrifugal force is proportional to the radius, this is the maximum radius for no-sliding.

3041.a.Problem Statement:
A photon of momentum $p$ impinges on a particle at rest of mass $m$.

What is the total relativistic energy of photon plus particle in the center of mass frame of reference?
3041.a.Solution:
Consider the quantity $E^{2}-P^{2} c^{2}$ of the system which is invariant under Lorentz transformation:

$$
\left(p c+m c^{2}\right)^{2}-p^{2} c^{2}=E^{\prime 2},
$$

where $E^{\prime}$ is total energy of the system in the center of mass frame, which is by definition the inertial frame in which the total momentum vanishes. Hence 

$$
E^{\prime}=\sqrt{2 p m c^{3}+m^{2} c^{4}} .
$$

2023.b.Problem Statement:
Two mass points $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}\left(m_{1} \neq m_{2}\right)$ are connected by a string of length $l$ passing through a hole in a horizontal table. The string and mass points move without friction with $m_{1}$ on the table and $m_{2}$ free to move in a vertical line.

If $m_{2}$ is slightly displaced in a vertical direction, small oscillations ensue. Use Lagrange's equations to find the period of these oscillations.
2023.b.Solution:
$m_{1}$ must have a velocity $v$ perpendicular to the string such that the centripetal force on it is equal to the gravitational force on $m_{2}$ :

$$
\frac{m_{1} v^{2}}{l-d}=m_{2} g
$$

or

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{m_{2}(l-d) g}{m_{1}}} .
$$

Use a frame of polar coordinates fixed in the horizontal table as shown in Fig. 2.19. $m_{2}$ has $z$-coordinate $-(l-r)$ and thus velocity $\dot{r}$. The Lagrangian of the system is then

$$
L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m_{1}\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} m_{2} \dot{r}^{2}+m_{2} g(l-r) .
$$

Lagrange's equations give

$$
\begin{gathered}
m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=\text { constant }, \\
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{1} r \dot{\theta}^{2}+m_{2} g=0 .
\end{gathered}
$$

At $t=0, r=l-d, v=\sqrt{m_{2}(l-d) g / m_{1}}=v_{0}$, say, so

$$
\dot{\theta}_{0}=\frac{v_{0}}{l-d}=\sqrt{\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}} \frac{g}{l-d}} .
$$

Hence

$$
m_{1} r^{2} \dot{\theta}=m_{1}(l-d)^{2} \dot{\theta}_{0}=m_{1} \sqrt{\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}}(l-d)^{3} g},
$$

giving

$$
r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{r^{4} \dot{\theta}^{2}}{r^{3}}=\frac{m_{2}}{m_{1}}\left(\frac{l-d}{r}\right)^{3} g
$$

and

$$
\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right) \ddot{r}-m_{2}\left(\frac{l-d}{r}\right)^{3} g+m_{2} g=0 .
$$

Let $r=(l-d)+\rho$, where $\rho \ll(l-d)$. Then

$$
\ddot{r}=\ddot{\rho}, \quad r^{-3}=(l-d)^{-3}\left(1+\frac{\rho}{l-d}\right)^{-3} \approx(l-d)^{-3}\left(1-\frac{3 \rho}{l-d}\right)
$$

and the above equation becomes

$$
\ddot{\rho}+\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)} \rho=0 .
$$

Hence $\rho$ oscillates about $O$, i.e. $r$ oscillates about the value $l-d$, with angular frequency

$$
\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3 m_{2} g}{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)}},
$$

or period

$$
T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{\left(m_{1}+m_{2}\right)(l-d)}{3 m_{2} g}}
$$

1235.b.Problem Statement:
A common lecture demonstration is as follows: hold or clamp a onemeter long thin aluminium bar at the center, strike one end longitudinally (i.e. parallel to the axis of the bar) with a hammer, and the result is a sound wave of frequency $2500 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

From this experiment, calculate the speed of sound in aluminium.
1235.b.Solution:
The point where the bar is struck is an antinode and the point where it is held a node. With the bar held at the center and its one end struck, the wavelength $\lambda$ is related to its length $L$ by $\lambda=2 L$. Hence the speed of sound propagation in the aluminium bar is

$$
v_{\mathrm{Al}}=\nu \lambda=2 \nu L=2 \times 2500 \times 1=5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \text {. }
$$

The speed of sound in a solid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{Y}{\rho}},
$$

where $Y$ is the Young's modulus of its material and $\rho$ its density. The speed of sound in a fluid is

$$
v=\sqrt{\frac{M}{\rho}}
$$

where $M$ is its bulk modulus and $\rho$ its density. For adiabatic compression of a gas, $M=\gamma p$, where $p$ is its pressure and $\gamma$ the ratio of its principal specific heats; $\gamma=1.4$ for air, a diatomic gas. Hence

$$
\frac{v_{\text {air }}}{v_{\mathrm{Al}}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.4 p \rho_{\mathrm{Al}}}{Y \rho_{\mathrm{air}}}} .
$$

With

$$
\begin{aligned}
p &=1.013 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \quad(\text { standard atmosphere) }\\
Y &=7.05 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{dyn} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \\
\rho_{\mathrm{Al}} &=2.7 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \\
\rho_{\text {air }} &=1.165 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cm}^{3} \quad\left(\text { at } 30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right) \\
v_{\text {air }} &=6.83 \times 10^{-2} \times 5000=341 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} .
\end{aligned}
$$$v_{\mathrm{Al}}=5000 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$.

1196.a.Problem Statement:
A small homogeneous sphere of mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls without sliding on the outer surface of a larger stationary sphere of radius $R$ as shown in the figure. Let $\theta$ be the polar angle of the small sphere with respect to a coordinate system with origin at the center of the large sphere and $z$-axis vertical. The smaller sphere starts from rest at the top of the larger sphere $(\theta=0)$

Calculate the velocity of the center of the small sphere as a function of $\theta$.
1196.a.Solution:
As the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of the small sphere is a constant of the motion when it rolls without sliding, we have 

$$
\frac{1}{2} m v^{2}+\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{5} m r^{2} \cdot \dot{\varphi}^{2}+m g(R+r) \cos \theta=m g(R+r)
$$

with $v=r \dot{\varphi}=(R+r) \dot{\theta}$, whence

$$
\dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7} \frac{(1-\cos \theta) g}{(R+r)}} .
$$

The velocity of the center of the small sphere is

$$
v=(R+r) \dot{\theta}=\sqrt{\frac{10}{7}(R+r)(1-\cos \theta) g} .
$$

1072.a.Problem Statement: A planet of mass $m$ is orbiting a star of mass $M$. The planet experiences a small drag force $\mathbf{F}=-\alpha \mathbf{v}$ due to motion through the star's dense atmosphere. Assuming an essentially circular orbit with radius $r=r_{0}$ at $t=0$, calculate the time dependence of the radius.
1072.a.Solution:
As the drag force $\mathbf{F}$ is small, it can be considered as a small perturbation on the circular motion of the planet under the gravitational force of the star. The unperturbed energy equation is

$$
E=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}\right)-\frac{G M m}{r} .
$$

If the orbit is circular with radius $r$, we have

and thus

$$
\dot{r}=0, \quad m r \dot{\theta}^{2}=\frac{m v^{2}}{r}=\frac{G M m}{r^{2}}
$$

$$
E=-\frac{G M m}{2 r} .
$$

The drag force causes energy loss at the rate

$$
-\mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{v}=\alpha \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{v}=\alpha v^{2}=\frac{\alpha G M}{r} .
$$

This must be equal to

$$
-\frac{d E}{d t}=-\frac{G M m \dot{r}}{2 r^{2}},
$$

giving rise to

$$
\dot{r}=-\frac{2 \alpha}{m} r,
$$

whose integration gives

$$
r=r_{0} e^{-\frac{2 \alpha t}{m}},
$$

where we have used $r=r_{0}$ at $t=0$.

3015.b.Problem Statement:
A mirror is moving through vacuum with relativistic speed $v$ in the $x$ direction. A beam of light with frequency $\omega_{i}$ is normally incident (from $x=+\infty$) on the mirror, as shown in the figure.

What is the energy of each reflected photon?
3015.b.Solution:
Let $\Sigma, \Sigma^{\prime}$ be the rest frames of the light source and observer, and of the mirror respectively. The transformation for angular frequency is given by

$$
\omega^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega-\beta c k_{x}\right), \quad \omega=\gamma\left(\omega^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right),
$$

where $\beta=\frac{v}{c}, \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}$. For the incident light, $\omega=\omega_{i}, k_{x}=-\frac{\omega_{i}}{c}$, the mirror perceives

$$
\omega_{i}^{\prime}=\gamma\left(\omega_{i}+\beta \omega_{i}\right)=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{i} .
$$

On reflection, $\omega_{r}^{\prime}=\omega_{i}^{\prime}$. The observer in $\Sigma$ will perceive

$$
\omega_{r}=\gamma\left(\omega_{r}^{\prime}+\beta c k_{x}^{\prime}\right)
$$

with $k_{x}^{\prime}=\omega_{r}^{\prime} / \mathrm{c}$, or

$$
\begin{aligned}
\omega_{r} &=\gamma(1+\beta) \omega_{r}^{\prime}=\gamma^{2}(1+\beta)^{2} \omega_{i} \\
&=\left(\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}\right) \omega_{i}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \dot{\omega}_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

as the angular frequency of the reflected light.The energy of each reflected photon is

$$
\hbar \omega_{r}=\left(\frac{c+v}{c-v}\right) \hbar \omega_{i} .
$$

1180.Problem Statement: A bowling ball of uniform density is thrown along a horizontal alley with initial velocity $v_{0}$ in such a way that it initially slides without rolling. The ball has mass $m$, coefficient of static friction $\mu_{s}$ and coefficient of sliding friction $\mu_{d}$ with the floor. Ignore the effect of air friction. Compute the velocity of the ball when it begins to roll without sliding.
1180.Solution:
When the bowling ball slides without rolling the friction $f=\mu_{d} m g$ gives rise to an acceleration

$$
a=-\frac{f}{m}=-\mu_{d} g .
$$

The moment of $f$ gives rise to an angular acceleration $\alpha$ given by

$$
f R=\frac{2}{5} M R^{2} \alpha
$$

as the ball has a moment of inertia $\frac{2}{5} m R^{2}$ about an axis through its center, $R$ being its radius. Suppose at time $t$ the ball begins to roll without sliding. We require

$$
R \alpha t=v_{0}+a t,
$$

giving

$$
t=\frac{v_{0}}{R \alpha-a}=\frac{2 m v_{0}}{7 f}=\frac{2 v_{0}}{7 \mu_{d} g} .
$$

The velocity of the ball when this happens is

$$
v=v_{0}+a t=v_{0}-\mu_{d} g t=\frac{5}{7} v_{0} .
$$

1136.a.Problem Statement: A rocket is fired straight up with no initial velocity. It is propelled by ejection of mass with a constant velocity of ejection $u$ relative to the rocket and at a constant rate so determined that the initial acceleration is zero. Assuming constant acceleration due to gravity, find the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time.
1136.a.Solution:
Let $v$ be the velocity of the rocket. The equation of motion is

$$
\frac{m d v}{d t}=-\frac{u d m}{d t}-m g .
$$

As $d m / d t=$ constant and $m=m_{0}, d v / d t=0$ at $t=0$, the above gives

$$
\frac{d m}{d t}=-\frac{m_{0} g}{u}
$$

at any time $t$ after firing. Integrating we obtain

$$
m=m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) .
$$

The equation of motion now becomes

$$
m_{0}\left(1-\frac{g t}{u}\right) \frac{d v}{d t}=\left(m_{0}-m\right) g=\frac{m_{0} g^{2} t}{u},
$$

or

$$
\frac{d v}{d t}=\frac{g^{2} t}{u-g t},
$$

which expresses the acceleration of the rocket as a function of time.

1134.Problem Statement: A chain with mass/length $=u$ hanging vertically from one end, where an upward force $F$ is applied to it, is lowered onto a table as shown in the figure. Find the equation of motion for $h$, the height of the end above the table ($h$ is the length of chain hanging freely).
1134.Solution:
As this problem involves variable mass it is more convenient to work with momentum. Consider the change of momentum of the chain during a time interval $t$ to $t+\Delta t$. If $h$ and $v$ are respectively the height and velocity of the freely-hanging portion of the chain at time $t$, its momentum is $\mu h v$ at $t$ and $\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)$ at $t+\Delta t$ (see Fig. 1.104). As a portion $\Delta h$ of the chain has reached the table and transferred a momentum $\approx \mu \Delta h v$ to the latter during the interval, the momentum theorem gives

$$
\mu(h-\Delta h)(v+\Delta v)+\mu \Delta h v-\mu h v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t,
$$

or, retaining only the first-order terms,

$$
\mu h \Delta v=(\mu h g-F) \Delta t .
$$

With $\Delta t \rightarrow 0$, the above becomes

$$
\mu h \dot{v}=\mu h g-F .
$$

As $v=-\dot{h}$, we have the equation of motion

$$
\ddot{h}=\frac{F}{\mu h}-g .
$$
